Q0.reasoning: Patient information explicitly states whole-exome sequencing (WES) has been ordered.

Q1.reasoning: Policy allows exome for nonsyndromic developmental delay with onset prior to age 18 (Standard Exome I.A.2.a); patient is an infant with developmental delay, so age criterion is met.

Q2.reasoning: Policy requires evaluation by a Board-Certified/Board-Eligible Medical Geneticist or APGN and counseling by appropriate providers (Standard Exome I.F and I.G). The patient data do not state the credentials of the ordering/referring provider or who performed the pre-test counseling, so adequacy vs policy cannot be determined.

Q3.reasoning: Patient meets a defined medical indication: unexplained developmental delay with onset <18 years (Standard Exome I.A.2.a). Family history further supports a likely genetic etiology.

Q4.reasoning: The policy does not mandate specific prior tests (e.g., CMA) as an absolute prerequisite; it requires alternate etiologies to be considered (Standard Exome I.B) and notes exome is often considered after CMA/panel testing, but no single explicit prior-test requirement is specified.

Q5.reasoning: Policy lists family history strongly suggestive of genetic etiology (including consanguinity) as a qualifying criterion (Standard Exome I.A.2.b(5)); patient has an older sibling with childhood hearing impairment consistent with relevant family history.

Q6.reasoning: Policy requires pre- and post-test counseling by an appropriate provider (Standard Exome I.F). Patient data state pre-test counseling was completed and post-test planned but do not specify the counselor's credentials, so compliance with the policy requirement cannot be confirmed.

Q7.reasoning: Policy coding table lists 81415 for standard exome sequencing (proband) and associates it with WES; the requested test is WES for a proband.

Q8.reasoning: While the patient meets a primary clinical indication (developmental delay), the policy requires additional criteria/documentation (e.g., consideration/rule-out of alternate etiologies, that presentation not fit a well-described syndrome, predicted impact on management, and evaluation/counseling by specified genetics providers per Standard Exome I.Bâ€“I.G). The provided patient information lacks documentation that these required elements (notably evaluation by a Board-Certified/Board-Eligible Medical Geneticist or APGN and qualified counseling provider credentials) have been met, so coverage per the policy cannot be confirmed.
